questionList.questionText: A 2-day-old boy is being evaluated in the nursery.  The patient was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 17-year-old primigravida.  The pregnancy was complicated by lack of prenatal care.  The delivery was uncomplicated, and the patient had Apgar scores of 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively.  He is formula-feeding well and has stooled twice but has had only a single wet diaper in the first 48 hours.  Weight is 2.89 kg (6 lb 6 oz), down 3% from birth weight.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the best next step in the evaluation of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Common causes of neonatal acute kidney injury

Prerenal disease

  • Hypovolemia
  • Cardiac disease
  • Sepsis

Intrinsic renal
disease

  • Acute tubular necrosis (eg, ischemic injury)
  • Nephrotoxins (eg, maternal NSAID use, aminoglycosides)
  • Renal vascular disease (eg, renal vein thrombosis)
  • Glomerular & cystic disease (eg, polycystic kidney disease)
  • Congenital anomalies (eg, renal agenesis)

Postrenal
disease

  • Obstructive uropathy (eg, posterior urethral valves)

NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

Normal urine output in a neonate is defined as ≥1 void per day of life; this infant has had only a single wet diaper in the first 48 hours of life and therefore has oliguria from neonatal acute kidney injury (AKI).  All neonates with oliguria require further evaluation with the following (Choice C):

  • History and physical examination to evaluate for possible risk factors (eg, nephrotoxins, family history, renal anomaly) and volume status (volume overload vs hypovolemia)
  • Renal and bladder ultrasound (RBUS), which documents the number, shape, and size of the kidney(s) and detects vascular abnormalities or congenital anomalies, which are particularly concerning in this patient with no prenatal care

An intravenous fluid bolus is often used when hypovolemia (eg, excessive weight loss, dry lips) from prerenal disease is the suspected cause of neonatal oliguria (Choice D).  However, establishing normal renal anatomy is required first because in neonates with obstructive uropathy or renal dysplasia, a fluid bolus could lead to volume overload, since the kidneys are unable to remove the excess fluid.  In addition, this patient has appropriate weight loss (<10% weight change at day 2) and is formula-feeding well, suggesting a normal volume status.

(Choice A)  An abdominal radiograph may reveal gross calcification or enlarged kidneys; however, ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality because it provides more detailed anatomy of the entire urinary tract and does not involve radiation.

(Choice B)  Bladder catheterization may be used to evaluate for and treat urinary retention.  However, renal ultrasound should be performed before attempting catheterization, which may cause injury if anatomy is abnormal.

(Choice F)  A voiding cystourethrogram provides detailed imaging of the distal urinary tract and can elucidate the reasons for pathology seen on renal bladder ultrasound (eg, reflux leading to hydronephrosis).  It is performed only if the ultrasound is abnormal because the procedure is invasive and involves radiation.

Educational objective:
Evaluation of neonatal acute kidney injury includes assessment of risk factors, volume status, and a renal and bladder ultrasound (RBUS).  RBUS documents the number, shape, and size of the kidneys and detects vascular abnormalities or congenital anomalies.

questionList.title: Acute kidney injury

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Prenatal diagnosis of congenital renal and urinary tract malformations.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office with a weeklong history of right hip pain.  Medical history is significant for hypertension and stage 4 chronic kidney disease.  Medications include a daily multivitamin, lisinopril, and amlodipine.  Vital signs are normal.  On physical examination, both internal and external rotation of the right hip elicit pain.  X-ray of the hip reveals a nondisplaced fracture of the right femoral neck and bilateral subperiosteal resorption.  Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to order?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's femoral neck fracture in the setting of advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD) should raise suspicion for secondary hyperparathyroidism.  Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a typical complication of CKD.  Parathyroid hormone (PTH) release is triggered by a low serum calcium level caused by the following:

  • Decreased renal phosphate excretion:  The resulting hyperphosphatemia leads to formation of calcium-phosphate complexes in the bloodstream (ie, binding of free calcium).
  • Decreased formation of active vitamin D:  The failing kidneys are less able to convert vitamin D3 (typically what is measured by the laboratory) to active 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, leading to reduced intestinal absorption, renal reabsorption, and bone mobilization of calcium.

PTH acts to increase serum calcium but, despite being persistently elevated, cannot fully overcome the disruption caused by the failing kidneys.

A major consequence of the persistently elevated PTH level is CKD-mineral bone disorder.  Ongoing increased bone turnover caused by elevated PTH can eventually lead to osteitis fibrosa cystica, a form of renal osteodystrophy characterized by reduced bone mineralization, marrow fibrosis, and increased fracture risk.  Subperiosteal resorption noted on x-ray (as in this patient) is highly specific for elevated PTH.

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is treated by reducing the serum phosphorus level (eg, dietary phosphate restriction, phosphate binders).  Overtreatment can increase the risk of adynamic bone disease (another form of renal osteodystrophy), which is characterized by low bone turnover and also increases fracture risk.

(Choice A)  Calcitonin can lower serum calcium level by inhibiting bone resorption.  However, its effect is relatively minor, and it does not have as significant a role in calcium regulation as PTH does.  Therefore, calcitonin concentration is not measured in the evaluation of CKD-mineral bone disorder.

(Choice B)  A CT scan can be helpful in diagnosing a hip fracture not visualized using x-ray.  Because an x-ray has already revealed that this patient has a hip fracture, a CT scan is not needed.

(Choice C)  A low estrogen level increases a patient's risk for osteoporosis and can predispose to fracture due to involvement of the inner trabecula (rather than the subperiosteal cortex).  Although the patient's age warrants consideration of conditions related to menopause, it falls nearer the younger end of the range.  This patient's advanced CKD should raise suspicion for secondary hyperparathyroidism.

(Choice D)  Hypermagnesemia can develop as CKD progresses, but it has not been shown to significantly contribute to mineral bone disorder.

Educational objective:
Chronic kidney disease predisposes patients to secondary hyperparathyroidism.  Persistently elevated parathyroid hormone can lead to osteitis fibrosa cystica, a form of renal osteodystrophy that causes subperiosteal bone resorption and increases fracture risk.

questionList.title: Chronic kidney disease

questionList.questionText:
A 72-year-old woman is brought to the office by her daughter for evaluation of leg swelling and fatigue.  The patient recently moved in with her daughter and has not seen a physician in several years.  She has had bilateral lower extremity swelling for the past 3 months.  The patient has had fatigue and joint pains for the past several years, which she attributes to old age.  The daughter states that the patient seems tired all the time, barely eats anything, and "is just not herself."  The patient takes no medication and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs.  Blood pressure is 116/72 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min and regular.  The lungs are clear on auscultation and heart sounds are normal.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  Examination of the lower extremities reveals 3+ pitting edema.  There are scattered ecchymoses, and hand examination findings are shown in the exhibit.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hemoglobin10.8 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume90 µm3
Platelets350,000/mm3
Leukocytes8,800/mm3
Serum chemistry
Creatinine0.9 mg/dL
Calcium9.1 mg/dL
Glucose94 mg/dL
Liver function studies
Albumin2.8 g/dL

Urinalysis reveals 4+ protein with no cells or casts.  A renal biopsy of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questionList.explanationText:
Major types of systemic amyloidosis

Primary

Secondary

Age related

Dialysis related

Disease
association

Plasma cell dyscrasia

Chronic infection/
inflammation

Elderly men

ESRD on dialysis

Precursor
protein

↓

Misfolding
mechanism

↓

Amyloid
fibril type

Immunoglobulin
light chains

↓

Increased
production

↓

AL

Serum
amyloid A

↓

Increased
production

↓

AA

Transthyretin
(prealbumin)

↓

Accumulation
over time

↓

ATTR*

β2-Microglobulin 
↓

Decreased
clearance

↓

Aβ2M

Clinical
manifestations

Nephropathy, hepatosplenomegaly, cardiomyopathy (AL > AA), peripheral neuropathy, macroglossia, skin bruising

Cardiomyopathy, CTS, other peripheral neuropathy

Scapulohumeral arthritis, CTS

Amyloid names begin with "A" followed by the precursor protein abbreviation.

*ATTR also occurs in a hereditary form that affects younger patients.

CTS = carpal tunnel syndrome; ESRD = end-stage renal disease.

This patient likely has nephrotic syndrome (ie, 4+ proteinuria, pitting edema, hypoalbuminemia).  In association with joint pains and characteristic hand deformities (eg, ulnar deviation, swan neck deformity, nodules), this presentation suggests rheumatoid arthritis (RA) complicated by AA amyloidosis.  Serum amyloid A protein is an acute phase reactant; therefore, AA amyloidosis often develops in the setting of chronic inflammation (eg, osteomyelitis, rheumatologic disease).  Long-standing RA is the most common cause, and patients with untreated RA are particularly susceptible.

The most common manifestation of AA amyloidosis is renal disease with proteinuria or nephrotic syndrome.  Skin involvement can lead to thickening or easy bruising (eg, ecchymoses).  Cardiac (eg, cardiomyopathy), gastrointestinal (eg, hepatomegaly, dysmotility), and neurologic (eg, peripheral neuropathy, dementia, stroke) disease may also occur.  Laboratory studies can show elevated inflammatory markers (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and normocytic anemia (due to chronic inflammation).

The diagnosis is confirmed with the presence of amyloid on tissue biopsy (eg, fat pad).  Renal biopsy can be considered if fat pad biopsy is nondiagnostic.  Histology demonstrates amorphous hyaline material that stains with Congo red; green birefringence is noted under polarized light.

(Choice B)  Proliferative glomerulonephritis demonstrates cellular proliferation and glomerular immune deposits on histology but usually presents with hypertension, hematuria, and red blood cell casts.  In addition, it is typically associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not RA.  Although SLE can cause arthralgias and arthritis (similar to those seen with RA), it typically presents in women of childbearing age and is associated with other findings (eg, thrombocytopenia, ulcers, malar rash).

(Choice C)  Hypertensive nephrosclerosis is characterized by hyalinization of the arterioles and small arteries and results in chronic kidney disease; however, it is caused by long-standing, uncontrolled hypertension (this patient's blood pressure is normal).  In addition, although proteinuria can occur with hypertensive nephrosclerosis, nephrotic-range proteinuria is unexpected (fatty casts on urine microscopy can be seen with nephrotic syndrome, but their absence does not exclude the diagnosis).

(Choice D)  Acute interstitial nephritis causes renal injury and is classically associated with certain drugs.  It can occur with systemic disease (eg, SLE) but is less commonly associated with RA.  It is typically characterized by fevers, rash, and urinary white blood cells and white blood cell casts.

(Choice E)  Hyperuricemia can result in urate deposition within the renal interstitium and can lead to renal injury, and gout can cause joint pain and deformity.  However, urate crystals are expected on urinalysis, and gout flares typically cause a monoarticular arthritis characterized by a warm, swollen, exquisitely painful joint.  This patient's ulnar deviation, swan neck deformity, and nodules are more consistent with RA (distal interphalangeal joint involvement is rare in RA and could suggest concomitant osteoarthritis).

Educational objective:
AA amyloidosis occurs in the setting of chronic inflammation and is most commonly seen in patients with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.  The most common manifestation is renal disease characterized by proteinuria and nephrotic syndrome; cardiac and gastrointestinal disease may also occur.  The diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy demonstrating amorphous hyaline material that stains with Congo red.

questionList.title: Amyloidosis

answerChoiceList.choice: Glomerular immune deposits and cellular proliferation
Hyalinization in the arterioles and small arteries
Urate crystal deposition in the interstitium

questionList.questionText:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother due to skin bruising, muscle aches, and fatigue.  She is concerned that these symptoms are due to him being bullied at school, which the boy denies.  He has also had significant nausea over the last week but has maintained adequate oral intake.  The patient has no chronic medical conditions.  Examination reveals mucosal pallor and numerous ecchymoses on the bilateral extremities.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin8.8 g/dL
    Platelets45,000/mm3
    Leukocytes28,800/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Sodium134 mEq/L
    Potassium5.2 mEq/L
    Chloride106 mEq/L
    Bicarbonate12 mEq/L
    Blood urea nitrogen64 mg/dL
    Creatinine4.2 mg/dL
Blood, plasma, and serum
    Lactate dehydrogenase, serum3,280 U/L
    Uric acid, serum18.6 mg/dL

Peripheral blood smear reveals significant immature myeloid cells.  Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's acute renal failure?
questionList.explanationText:
This boy's hematologic findings of anemia (eg, fatigue, pallor), thrombocytopenia (eg, ecchymoses), and leukocytosis with immature myeloid forms suggest acute myelogenous leukemia (AML).  Concurrent hyperkalemia, hyperuricemia, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and acute kidney injury (AKI) (with resultant acidosis) raises suspicion for spontaneous tumor lysis syndrome (TLS).  Although most cases of TLS occur following initiation of cytotoxic chemotherapy, some hematologic malignancies (eg, AML) with high tumor cell burdens or rapid replication rates can cause TLS in the absence of chemotherapy due to massive, spontaneous tumor cell lysis.

TLS is marked by the release of intracellular tumor contents into the bloodstream, leading to:

  • Hyperuricemia:  purine nucleic acids from lysed tumor cells are metabolized by xanthine oxidase to uric acid.  Because uric acid is poorly soluble in urine, patients often develop obstructing uric acid stones in the renal tubules, which causes AKI.

  • Hyperphosphatemia:  tumor cells frequently contain >3 times more intracellular phosphate than healthy cells.  Phosphate (renally excreted) binds calcium in the renal tubules and forms obstructing calcium-phosphate stones; this can also cause AKI and leads to systemic hypocalcemia.

  • Hyperkalemia:  intracellular potassium is released into the circulation, which can cause cardiac arrhythmias.

Other common manifestations of TLS include nausea, vomiting, myalgia, and fatigue.  Aggressive intravenous hydration, uric acid reduction (eg, rasburicase, allopurinol), and treatment of electrolyte abnormalities is required to prevent long-term sequalae and death.

(Choices A and C)  Multiple myeloma (MM) frequently causes AKI due to obstructing light-chain casts; in some cases of MM, renal failure may be due to concurrent amyloidosis.  Although hematologic abnormalities (eg, normocytic anemia, thrombocytopenia) can be seen with MM and amyloidosis, these conditions are very rare in children, do not typically cause significant hyperuricemia, and would not explain immature myeloid cells on peripheral smear.

(Choices B, D, and F)  Interstitial nephritis is typically associated with concurrent medication use (eg, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), infection, or rheumatologic disease.  Proliferative glomerulonephritis can be seen in certain solid organ malignancies.  Urethral obstruction can impair urinary excretion.  Although these conditions can cause AKI, the elevated uric acid and LDH levels and the immature myeloid forms make spontaneous TLS far more likely.

Educational objective:
Spontaneous tumor lysis syndrome can occur in patients who have hematologic malignancies with high tumor burden or rapid replication rate.  It typically presents with acute kidney injury due to the formation of uric acid and calcium-phosphate stones and/or complications (eg, cardiac arrhythmia) from hyperkalemia.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Tumor lysis syndrome

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS)
Hematological malignancies presenting as spontaneous tumor lysis syndrome: a case series.

questionList.questionText: A 19-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to recurrent headaches.  The patient has had headaches for years but thinks they have recently gotten worse; they last several hours and remit spontaneously or after taking over-the-counter acetaminophen.  She has no nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, sweating, or fever.  Six months ago, the patient checked her blood pressure at a local pharmacy and was told it was high.  She has no other medical issues and takes no prescription medications.  Her family history is significant for hypertension and diabetes.  Blood pressure is 175/100 mm Hg on the right arm and 170/102 mm Hg on the left arm, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 14/min.  On examination, she appears comfortable and cooperative.  Peripheral pulses are full and symmetric.  Chest examination is unremarkable.  A systolic bruit is heard under the right ear.  Abdominal examination shows no tenderness or masses.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hypertension?
questionList.explanationText:
Fibromuscular dysplasia

Clinical presentation

  • 90% women (in adults)
  • Internal carotid artery stenosis
    • Recurrent headache
    • Pulsatile tinnitus
    • Transient ischemic attack
    • Stroke
  • Renal artery stenosis
    • Secondary hypertension
    • Flank pain

Physical examination

  • Subauricular systolic bruit
  • Abdominal bruit

Diagnosis

  • Imaging preferred (eg, duplex US, CTA, MRA)
  • Catheter-based arteriography

Treatment

  • Antihypertensives (ACE inhibitors or ARBs 1st line)
  • PTA
  • Surgery (if PTA unsuccessful)
ARB = angiotensin II receptor blocker; CTA = CT angiography; MRA = MR angiography; PTA = percutaneous transluminal angioplasty; US = ultrasonography.

This patient most likely has secondary hypertension due to fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD).  FMD is a systemic noninflammatory disease that typically affects the renal and internal carotid arteries and leads to arterial stenosis, aneurysm, or dissection.  Less commonly, the vertebral, iliac, or mesenteric arteries can be affected.

In adults, approximately 90% of FMD cases occur in women.  Recurrent headache caused by carotid artery stenosis or aneurysm is the most common presenting symptom.  Pulsatile tinnitus, neck pain, or flank pain are also common, and symptoms of transient ischemic attack (eg, focal weakness, vision loss) may occur.  Hypertension results from renal artery stenosis (RAS) leading to secondary hyperaldosteronism.  An abdominal bruit may be present.  In young patients, a subauricular systolic bruit is highly suggestive of FMD as carotid atherosclerosis should not be present.  Even in older patients, such a bruit suggests FMD as the subauricular location indicates involvement of the internal carotid artery, which, in contrast with the carotid bulb, is not commonly affected by atherosclerosis.

Diagnosis of FMD is typically made by vascular imaging (eg, duplex ultrasonography, CT or magnetic resonance angiography).  For patients with hypertension, treatment involves antihypertensive medication (eg, ACE inhibitor) and definitive management of RAS with either percutaneous transluminal angioplasty or surgery.

(Choice A)  Aortic coarctation presents with upper extremity hypertension, headaches, and lower extremity claudication.  This patient has full peripheral (upper and lower extremity) pulses, making aortic coarctation unlikely.

(Choice C)  Pheochromocytomas cause secondary hypertension due to secretion of catecholamines.  Typical presentation is with episodic headaches, sweating, and tachycardia.  A carotid bruit is not typical.

(Choice D)  Primary hyperaldosteronism (adrenal adenoma) is associated with secondary hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.  Bruits are not typical.

(Choice E)  RAS due to atherosclerosis can cause secondary hypertension.  However, renal atherosclerosis is extremely unlikely in this young woman in the absence of a familial hypercholesterolemia.

Educational objective:
In adults, fibromuscular dysplasia most commonly affects women.  Headaches due to internal carotid artery stenosis and secondary hypertension due to renal artery stenosis are common presentations.  Accompanying bruits may be found in the neck and abdomen.

questionList.title: Renal artery stenosis

questionList.questionText:
A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to increasing abdominal distension and discomfort for 1 week.  He also reports a marked decrease in urine output over the last 2 days.  Medical history is significant for cirrhosis due to alcohol use.  The patient takes furosemide and spironolactone with no recent dose changes.  Temperature is 36.5 C (97.7 F), blood pressure is 91/55 mm Hg, pulse is 116/min, and respirations are 18/min.  The abdomen is distended and nontender with positive shifting dullness and has normal bowel sounds.  There is 2+ lower extremity pitting edema.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Hemoglobin10.7 g/dL
Leukocytes6,200/mm3
Sodium130 mEq/L
Potassium5.0 mEq/L
Chloride103 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen63 mg/dL
Creatinine2.4 mg/dL

Urine dipstick is negative for protein and blood.  Serum creatinine 3 weeks ago was 1.1 mg/dL.  Renal ultrasound shows no abnormalities.  Analysis of abdominal fluid shows a leukocyte count of 160/mm3 with 30% neutrophils.  Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosing the cause of this patient's acute kidney injury?
questionList.explanationText:
Evaluation of acute kidney injury (AKI) includes ruling out urinary obstruction and collecting a sample for urinalysis.  This patient's normal renal ultrasound excludes obstruction (ie, postrenal AKI); a bland urinalysis (eg, no protein or blood) makes intrinsic AKI unlikely.  In contrast to classic prerenal AKI that resolves with volume expansion, patients with cirrhosis can develop a severe form of prerenal AKI called hepatorenal syndrome (HRS).

HRS is driven by a neurohormonal cascade involving splanchnic vasodilation that shunts blood away from the kidneys—which results in severe hyperactivity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).  This leads to extreme sodium reabsorption, which causes ascites that can become diuretic resistant (as in this patient).  RAAS hyperactivity also causes profound renal vasoconstriction that leads to rapidly progressive (often oliguric) AKI.

Due to the remarkable renal sodium avidity in HRS, a very low urine sodium (<10 mEq/L vs <20 mEq/L in classic prerenal AKI) is a helpful diagnostic clue.  A lack of improvement with volume expansion (eg, intravenous albumin) helps confirm the diagnosis since the underlying cause is altered splanchnic and renal blood flow.

(Choice A)  CT scan of the abdomen can further investigate causes of postrenal AKI (eg, tumor compressing both ureters).  However, this patient's normal renal ultrasonography excludes urinary obstruction.

(Choice B)  Kidney biopsy is rarely needed for suspected HRS, which is typically a clinical diagnosis.  Moreover, the kidneys maintain a relatively normal histologic appearance in HRS.

(Choice C)  Serum complement levels are often low in patients with glomerulonephritis, which typically presents with proteinuria and hematuria (absent in this patient).

(Choice D)  Urine protein electrophoresis is used to evaluate for multiple myeloma, which can cause AKI with a bland urinalysis (ie, cast nephropathy).  However, multiple myeloma is a less likely cause of AKI than HRS in this patient with cirrhosis and ascites.  Anemia is a nonspecific finding that is commonly seen in both multiple myeloma and cirrhosis.

Educational objective:
Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) is a severe form of prerenal acute kidney injury that is caused by significant splanchnic vasodilation leading to renal hypoperfusion.  HRS is diagnosed in the presence of a bland urinalysis, very low urine sodium (<10 mEq/L), and lack of response to volume expansion.
